25.18: His descendants lived as nomads from the region of Havilah to Shur, which is near Egypt, in the direction of Assyria. They all fought with each other.
25.19: This is the account of Abraham's son Isaac and his descendants. Abraham was the father of Isaac.
25.20: Isaac was 40 years old when he married Rebekah, daughter of Bethuel the Aramean from Paddan Aram and sister of Laban the Aramean.
25.21: Isaac prayed to the LORD for his wife because she was childless. The LORD answered his prayer, and his wife Rebekah became pregnant.
25.22: When the children inside her were struggling with each other, she said, "If it's like this now, what will become of me?" So she went to ask the LORD.
25.23: The LORD said to her, "Two countries are in your womb. Two nations will go their separate ways from birth. One nation will be stronger than the other, and the older will serve the younger."
25.24: When the time came for her to give birth, she had twins.
25.25: The first one born was red. His whole body was covered with hair, so they named him Esau [Hairy].
25.26: Afterwards, his brother was born with his hand holding on to Esau's heel, and so he was named Jacob [Heel]. Isaac was 60 years old when they were born.
25.27: They grew up. Esau became an expert hunter, an outdoorsman. Jacob remained a quiet man, staying around the tents.
25.28: Because Isaac liked to eat the meat of wild animals, he loved Esau. However, Rebekah loved Jacob.
25.29: Once, Jacob was preparing a meal when Esau, exhausted, came in from outdoors.
25.30: So Esau said to Jacob, "Let me have the whole pot of red stuff to eat-that red stuff-I'm exhausted." This is why he was called Edom.
25.31: Jacob responded, "First, sell me your rights as firstborn."
25.32: "I'm about to die." Esau said. "What good is my inheritance to me?"
25.33: "First, swear an oath," Jacob said. So Esau swore an oath to him and sold him his rights as firstborn.
25.34: Then Jacob gave Esau a meal of bread and lentils. He ate and drank, and then he got up and left. This is how Esau showed his contempt for his rights as firstborn.

26.1: There was a famine in the land in addition to the earlier one during Abraham's time. So Isaac went to King Abimelech of the Philistines in Gerar.
26.2: The LORD appeared to Isaac and said, "Don't go to Egypt. Stay where I tell you.
26.3: Live here in this land for a while, and I will be with you and bless you. I will give all these lands to you and your descendants. I will keep the oath that I swore to your father Abraham.
26.4: I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars in the sky and give all these lands to your descendants. Through your descendant all the nations of the earth will be blessed.
26.5: I will bless you because Abraham obeyed me and completed the duties, commands, laws, and instructions I gave him."
26.7: When the men of that place asked about his wife, Isaac answered, "She's my sister." He was afraid to say "my wife." He thought that the men of that place would kill him to get Rebekah, because she was an attractive woman.
26.8: When he had been there a long time, King Abimelech of the Philistines looked out of his window and saw Isaac caressing his wife Rebekah.
26.9: Abimelech called for Isaac and said, "So she's really your wife! How could you say, 'She's my sister'?" Isaac answered him, "I thought I would be killed because of her."
26.10: Then Abimelech said, "What have you done to us! One of the people might have easily gone to bed with your wife, and then you would have made us guilty of sin."
26.11: So Abimelech ordered his people, "Anyone who touches this man or his wife will be put to death."
26.12: Isaac planted [crops] in that land. In that same year he harvested a hundred times as much as he had planted because the LORD had blessed him.
26.13: He continued to be successful, becoming very rich.
26.14: Because he owned so many flocks, herds, and servants, the Philistines became jealous of him.
26.15: So the Philistines filled in all the wells that his father's servants had dug during his father Abraham's lifetime.
26.16: Finally, Abimelech said to Isaac, "Go away from us! You've become more powerful than we are."
26.17: So Isaac moved away. He set up his tents in the Gerar Valley and lived there.
26.18: He dug out the wells that had been dug during his father Abraham's lifetime. The Philistines had filled them in after Abraham's death. He gave them the same names that his father had given them.
26.19: Isaac's servants dug in the valley and found a spring-fed well.
26.20: The herders from Gerar quarreled with Isaac's herders, claiming, "This water is ours!" So Isaac named the well Esek [Argument], because they had argued with him.
26.21: Then they dug another well, and they quarreled over that one too. So Isaac named it Sitnah [Accusation].
26.22: He moved on from there and dug another well. They didn't quarrel over this one. So he named it Rehoboth [Roomy] and said, "Now the LORD has made room for us, and we will prosper in this land."
26.23: He went from there to Beersheba.
26.24: That night the LORD appeared to Isaac, and said, "I am the God of your father Abraham. Don't be afraid, because I am with you. I will bless you and increase the number of your descendants for my servant Abraham's sake."
26.25: So Isaac built an altar there and worshiped the LORD. He also pitched his tent in that place, and his servants dug a well there.
26.26: Abimelech, his friend Ahuzzath, and Phicol, the commander of his army, came from Gerar to see Isaac.
26.27: Isaac asked them, "Why have you come to me, since you hate me and sent me away from you?"
26.28: They answered, "We have seen that the LORD is with you. So we thought, 'There should be a solemn agreement between us.' We'd like to make an agreement with you
26.29: that you will not harm us, since we have not touched you. We have done only good to you and let you go in peace. Now you are blessed by the LORD."
26.30: Isaac prepared a special dinner for them, and they ate and drank.
26.31: Early the next morning they exchanged oaths. Then Isaac sent them on their way, and they left peacefully.
26.32: That same day Isaac's servants came and told him about a well they had dug. They said to him, "We've found water."
26.33: So he named it Shibah [Oath]. That is why the name of the city is still Beersheba today.
26.34: When Esau was 40 years old, he married Judith, daughter of Beeri the Hittite. He also married Basemath, daughter of Elon the Hittite.
26.35: These women brought Isaac and Rebekah a lot of grief.

27.1: When Isaac was old and going blind, he called his older son Esau and said to him, "Son!" Esau answered, "Here I am."
27.2: Isaac said, "I'm old. I don't know when I'm going to die.
27.3: Now take your hunting equipment, your quiver and bow, and go out into the open country and hunt some wild game for me.
27.4: Prepare a good-tasting meal for me, just the way I like it. Bring it to me to eat so that I will bless you before I die."
27.5: Rebekah was listening while Isaac was speaking to his son Esau. When Esau went into the open country to hunt for some wild game to bring back,
27.6: Rebekah said to her son Jacob, "I've just heard your father speaking to your brother Esau.
27.7: He said, 'Bring me some wild game, and prepare a good-tasting meal for me to eat so that I will bless you in the presence of the LORD before I die.'
27.8: Now listen to me, Son, and do what I tell you.
27.9: Go to the flock, and get me two good young goats. I'll prepare them as a good-tasting meal for your father, just the way he likes it.
27.10: Then take it to your father to eat so that he will bless you before he dies."
27.11: Jacob said to his mother Rebekah, "My brother Esau is a hairy man, and my skin is smooth.
27.12: My father will feel [my skin] and think I'm mocking him. Then I'll bring a curse on myself instead of a blessing."
27.13: His mother responded, "Let any curse on you fall on me, Son. Just obey me and go! Get me [the young goats]."
27.14: He went and got them and brought them to his mother. She prepared a good-tasting meal, just the way his father liked it.
27.15: Then Rebekah took her older son Esau's good clothes, which she had in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob.
27.16: She put the skins from the young goats on his hands and on the back of his neck.
27.17: Then she gave her son Jacob the good-tasting meal and the bread she had prepared.
27.18: He went to his father and said, "Father?" "Yes?" he answered. "Who are you, Son?"
27.19: Jacob answered his father, "I'm Esau, your firstborn. I've done what you told me. Sit up and eat this meat I've hunted for you so that you may bless me."
27.20: Isaac asked his son, "How did you find it so quickly, Son?" "The LORD your God brought it to me," he answered.
27.21: Then Isaac said to Jacob, "Come over here so that I can feel your skin, Son, [to find out] whether or not you really are my son Esau."
27.22: So Jacob went over to his father. Isaac felt [his skin]. "The voice is Jacob's," he said, "but the hands are Esau's."
27.23: He didn't recognize Jacob, because his hands were hairy like his brother Esau's hands. So he blessed him.
27.24: "Are you really my son Esau?" he asked him. "I am," Jacob answered.
27.25: Isaac said, "Bring me some of the game, and I will eat it, Son, so that I will bless you." Jacob brought it to Isaac, and he ate it. Jacob also brought him wine, and he drank it.
27.26: Then his father Isaac said to him, "Come here and give me a kiss, Son."
27.27: He went over and gave him a kiss. When Isaac smelled his clothes, he blessed him and said, "The smell of my son is like the smell of open country that the LORD has blessed.
27.28: May God give you dew from the sky, fertile fields on the earth, and plenty of fresh grain and new wine.
27.29: May nations serve you. May people bow down to you. Be the master of your brothers, and may the sons of your mother bow down to you. May those who curse you be cursed. May those who bless you be blessed."
27.30: Isaac finished blessing Jacob. Jacob had barely left when his brother Esau came in from hunting.
27.31: He, too, prepared a good-tasting meal and brought it to his father. Then he said to his father, "Please, Father, eat some of the meat I've hunted for you so that you will bless me."
27.32: "Who are you?" his father Isaac asked him. "I'm your firstborn son Esau," he answered.
27.33: Trembling violently all over, Isaac asked, "Who hunted game and brought it to me? I ate it before you came in. I blessed him, and he will stay blessed."
27.34: When Esau heard these words from his father, he shouted out a very loud and bitter cry and said to his father, "Bless me too, Father!"
27.35: Isaac said, "Your brother came and deceived me and has taken away your blessing."
27.36: Esau said, "Isn't that why he's named Jacob? He's cheated me twice already: He took my rights as firstborn, and now he's taken my blessing." So he asked, "Haven't you saved a blessing for me?"
27.37: Isaac answered Esau, "I have made him your master, and I have made all his brothers serve him. I've provided fresh grain and new wine for him. What is left for me to do for you, Son?"
27.38: Esau asked, "Do you have only one blessing, Father? Bless me too, Father!" And Esau sobbed loudly.
27.39: His father Isaac answered him, "The place where you live will lack the fertile fields of the earth and the dew from the sky above.
27.40: You will use your sword to live, and you will serve your brother. But eventually you will gain your freedom and break his yoke off your neck."
27.41: So Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing that his father had given him. Esau said to himself, "The time to mourn for my father is near. Then I'll kill my brother Jacob."
27.42: When Rebekah was told what her older son Esau had said, she sent for her younger son Jacob and said to him, "Watch out! Your brother Esau is comforting himself by planning to kill you.
27.43: So now, Son, obey me. Quick! Run away to my brother Laban in Haran.
27.44: Stay with him awhile, until your brother's anger cools down.
27.45: When your brother's anger is gone and he has forgotten what you did to him, I'll send for you and get you back. Why should I lose both of you in one day?"
27.46: Rebekah said to Isaac, "I can't stand Hittite women! If Jacob marries a Hittite woman like one of those from around here, I might as well die."

28.1: Isaac called for Jacob and blessed him. Then he commanded him, "You are not to marry any of the Canaanite women.
28.2: Quick! Go to Paddan Aram. Go to the home of Bethuel, your mother's father, and get yourself a wife from there from the daughters of your uncle Laban.
28.3: May God Almighty bless you, make you fertile, and increase the number of your descendants so that you will become a community of people.
28.4: May he give to you and your descendants the blessing of Abraham so that you may take possession of the land where you are now living, the land that God gave to Abraham."
28.5: Isaac sent Jacob to Paddan Aram. Jacob went to live with Laban, son of Bethuel the Aramean and brother of Rebekah. She was the mother of Jacob and Esau.
28.6: Esau learned that Isaac had blessed Jacob and had sent him away to Paddan Aram to get a wife from there. He learned that Isaac had blessed Jacob and had commanded him not to marry any of the Canaanite women.
28.7: He also learned that Jacob had obeyed his father and mother and had left for Paddan Aram.
28.8: Esau realized that his father Isaac disapproved of Canaanite women.
28.9: So he went to Ishmael and married Mahalath, daughter of Abraham's son Ishmael and sister of Nebaioth, in addition to the wives he had.
28.10: Jacob left Beersheba and traveled toward Haran.
28.11: When he came to a certain place, he stopped for the night because the sun had gone down. He took one of the stones from that place, put it under his head, and lay down there.
28.12: He had a dream in which he saw a stairway set up on the earth with its top reaching up to heaven. He saw the angels of God going up and coming down on it.
28.13: The LORD was standing above it, saying, "I am the LORD, the God of your grandfather Abraham and the God of Isaac. I will give the land on which you are lying to you and your descendants.
28.14: Your descendants will be like the dust on the earth. You will spread out to the west and to the east, to the north and to the south. Through you and through your descendant every family on earth will be blessed.
28.15: Remember, I am with you and will watch over you wherever you go. I will also bring you back to this land because I will not leave you until I do what I've promised you."
28.16: Then Jacob woke up from his sleep and exclaimed, "Certainly, the LORD is in this place, and I didn't know it!"
28.17: Filled with awe, he said, "How awe-inspiring this place is! Certainly, this is the house of God and the gateway to heaven!"
28.18: Early the next morning Jacob took the stone he had put under his head. He set it up as a marker and poured olive oil on top of it.
28.19: He named that place Bethel [House of God]. Previously, the name of the city was Luz.
28.20: Then Jacob made a vow: "If God will be with me and will watch over me on my trip and give me food to eat and clothes to wear,
28.21: and if I return safely to my father's home, then the LORD will be my God.
28.22: This stone that I have set up as a marker will be the house of God, and I will surely give you a tenth of everything you give me."

29.1: Jacob continued on his trip and came to the land in the east.
29.2: He looked around, and out in a field he saw a well with a large stone over the opening. Three flocks of sheep were lying down near it, because the flocks were watered from that well.
29.3: When all the flocks were gathered there, the stone would be rolled off the opening of the well so that the sheep could be watered. Then the stone would be put back in place over the opening of the well.
29.4: Jacob asked some people, "My friends, where are you from?" "We're from Haran," they replied.
29.5: He asked them, "Do you know Laban, Nahor's grandson?" They answered, "We do."
29.6: "How is he doing?" Jacob asked them. "He's fine," they answered. "Here comes his daughter Rachel with the sheep."
29.7: "It's still the middle of the day," he said. "It isn't time yet to gather the livestock. Water the sheep. Then let them graze."
29.8: They replied, "We can't until all the flocks are gathered. When the stone is rolled off the opening of the well, we can water the sheep."
29.9: While he was still talking to them, Rachel arrived with her father's sheep, because she was a shepherd.
29.10: Jacob saw Rachel, daughter of his uncle Laban, with his uncle Laban's sheep. He came forward and rolled the stone off the opening of the well and watered his uncle Laban's sheep.
29.11: Then Jacob kissed Rachel and sobbed loudly.
29.12: When Jacob told Rachel that he was her father's nephew and that he was Rebekah's son, she ran and told her father.
29.13: As soon as Laban heard the news about his sister's son Jacob, he ran to meet him. He hugged and kissed him and brought him into his home. Then Jacob told Laban all that had happened.
29.14: Laban said to him, "You are my own flesh and blood." Jacob stayed with him for a whole month.
29.15: Then Laban said to him, "Just because you're my relative doesn't mean that you should work for nothing. Tell me what your wages should be."
29.16: Laban had two daughters. The name of the older one was Leah, and the name of the younger one was Rachel.
29.17: Leah had attractive eyes, but Rachel had a beautiful figure and beautiful features.
29.18: Jacob loved Rachel. So he offered, "I'll work seven years in return for your younger daughter Rachel."
29.19: Laban responded, "It's better that I give her to you than to any other man. Stay with me."
29.20: Jacob worked seven years in return for Rachel, but the years seemed like only a few days to him because he loved her.
29.21: [At the end of the seven years] Jacob said to Laban, "The time is up; give me my wife! I want to sleep with her."
29.22: So Laban invited all the people of that place and gave a wedding feast.
29.23: In the evening he took his daughter Leah and brought her to Jacob. Jacob slept with her. When morning came, he realized it was Leah.
29.24: (Laban had given his slave Zilpah to his daughter Leah as her slave.)
29.25: "What have you done to me?" Jacob asked Laban. "Didn't I work for you in return for Rachel? Why did you cheat me?"
29.26: Laban answered, "It's not our custom to give the younger daughter [in marriage] before the older one.
29.27: Finish the week of wedding festivities with this daughter. Then we will give you the other one too. But you'll have to work for me another seven years."
29.28: That's what Jacob did. He finished the week with Leah. Then Laban gave his daughter Rachel to him as his wife.
29.29: (Laban had given his slave Bilhah to his daughter Rachel as her slave.)
29.30: Jacob slept with Rachel too. He loved Rachel more than Leah. So he worked for Laban another seven years.
29.31: When the LORD saw Leah was unloved, he made it possible for her to have children, but Rachel had none.
29.32: Leah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Reuben [Here's My Son], because she said, "Certainly, the LORD has seen my misery; now my husband will love me!"
29.33: She became pregnant again and gave birth to another son. She said, "Certainly, the LORD has heard that I'm unloved, and he also has given me this son." So she named him Simeon [Hearing].
29.34: She became pregnant again and gave birth to another son. She said, "Now at last my husband will become attached to me because I've given him three sons." So she named him Levi [Attached].
29.35: She became pregnant again and gave birth to another son. She said, "This time I will praise the LORD." So she named him Judah [Praise]. Then she stopped having children.

30.1: Rachel saw that she could not have children for Jacob, and she became jealous of her sister. She said to Jacob, "Give me children, or I'll die!"
30.2: Jacob became angry with Rachel and asked, "Can I take the place of God, who has kept you from having children?"
30.3: She said, "Here's my servant Bilhah. Sleep with her. She can have children for me, and I can build a family for myself through her."
30.4: So she gave him her slave Bilhah as his wife, and Jacob slept with her.
30.5: Bilhah became pregnant, and she gave birth to a son for Jacob.
30.6: Rachel said, "Now God has judged in my favor. He has heard my prayer and has given me a son." So she named him Dan [He Judges].
30.7: Rachel's slave Bilhah became pregnant again and gave birth to a second son for Jacob.
30.8: Rachel said, "I have had a great struggle with my sister, and I have won!" So she named him Naphtali [My Struggle].
30.9: When Leah saw that she had stopped having children, she took her slave Zilpah and gave her to Jacob as his wife.
30.10: Leah's slave Zilpah gave birth to a son for Jacob.
30.11: Leah said, "I've been lucky!" So she called him Gad [Luck].
30.12: Leah's slave Zilpah gave birth to her second son for Jacob.
30.13: Leah said, "I've been blessed! Women will call me blessed." So she named him Asher [Blessing].
30.14: During the wheat harvest Reuben went out into the fields and found some mandrakes. He brought them to his mother Leah. Rachel said to Leah, "Please give me some of your son's mandrakes."
30.15: Leah replied, "Isn't it enough that you took my husband? Are you also going to take my son's mandrakes?" Rachel said, "Very well, Jacob can go to bed with you tonight in return for your son's mandrakes."
30.16: As Jacob was coming in from the fields that evening, Leah went out to meet him. "You are to sleep with me," she said. "You are my reward for my son's mandrakes." So he went to bed with her that night.
30.17: God answered Leah's prayer. She became pregnant and gave birth to her fifth son for Jacob.
30.18: Leah said, "God has given me my reward because I gave my slave to my husband." So she named him Issachar [Reward].
30.19: She became pregnant again and gave birth to her sixth son for Jacob.
30.20: Leah said, "God has presented me with a beautiful present. This time my husband will honor me because I have given him six sons." So she named him Zebulun [Honor].
30.21: Later she gave birth to a daughter and named her Dinah.
30.22: Then God remembered Rachel. God answered her prayer and made it possible for her to have children.
30.23: So she became pregnant and gave birth to a son. Then she said, "God has taken away my disgrace."
30.24: She named him Joseph [May He Give Another] and said, "May the LORD give me another son."
30.25: After Rachel gave birth to Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, "Let me go home to my own country.
30.26: Give me my wives and my children for whom I've worked, and let me go. You know how much work I've done for you."
30.27: Laban replied, "Listen to me. I've learned from the signs I've seen that the LORD has blessed me because of you."
30.28: So he offered, "Name your wages, and I'll pay them."
30.29: Jacob responded, "You know how much work I've done for you and what has happened to your livestock under my care.
30.30: The little that you had before I came has grown to a large amount. The LORD has blessed you wherever I've been. When can I do something for my own family?"
30.31: Laban asked, "What should I give you?" "Don't give me anything," Jacob answered. "Instead, do something for me, then I'll go back to taking care of and watching your flocks again.
30.32: Let me go through all of your flocks today and take every speckled or spotted sheep, every black lamb, and every spotted or speckled goat. They will be my wages.
30.33: My honesty will speak for itself whenever you come to check on my wages. Any goat I have that isn't speckled or spotted or any lamb that isn't black will be considered stolen."
30.34: Laban answered, "Agreed. We'll do as you've said."
30.35: However, that same day Laban took out the striped and spotted male goats, all the speckled and spotted female goats (every one with white on it), and every black lamb. He had his sons take charge of them.
30.36: He traveled three days away from Jacob. Jacob continued to take care of the rest of Laban's flocks.
30.37: Then Jacob took fresh-cut branches of poplar, almond, and plane trees and peeled the bark on them in strips of white, uncovering the white which was on the branches.
30.38: He placed the peeled branches in the troughs directly in front of the flocks, at the watering places where the flocks came to drink. When they were in heat and came to drink,
30.39: they mated in front of the branches. Then they gave birth to young that were striped, speckled, or spotted.
30.40: Jacob separated the rams from the flock and made the rest of the sheep face any that were striped or black in Laban's flocks. So he made separate herds for himself and did not add them to Laban's flocks.
30.41: Whenever the stronger of the flocks were in heat, Jacob would lay the branches in the troughs in front of them so that they would mate by the branches.
30.42: But when the flocks in heat were weak, he didn't lay down the branches. So the weaker ones belonged to Laban and the stronger ones to Jacob.
30.43: As a result, Jacob became very wealthy. He had large flocks, male and female slaves, camels, and donkeys.

31.1: Jacob heard that Laban's sons were saying, "Jacob has taken everything that belonged to our father and has gained all his wealth from him."
31.2: He also noticed that Laban did not appear as friendly to him as before.
31.3: Then the LORD said to Jacob, "Go back to the land of your ancestors and to your relatives, and I will be with you."
31.4: So Jacob sent a message to Rachel and Leah to come out to the open country where his flocks were.
31.5: He said to them, "I have seen that your father isn't as friendly to me as he was before, but the God of my father has been with me.
31.6: You know that I have worked as hard as I could for your father.
31.7: Your father has cheated me. He has changed my wages ten times. But God hasn't let him harm me.
31.8: Whenever he said, 'The speckled ones will be your wages,' all the flocks gave birth to speckled young. And whenever he said, 'The striped ones will be your wages,' all the flocks gave birth to striped young.
31.9: So God has taken away your father's livestock and has given them to me.
31.10: "During the mating season I had a dream: I looked up and saw that the male goats which were mating were striped, speckled, or spotted.
31.11: In the dream the Messenger of God called to me, 'Jacob!' And I answered, 'Yes, here I am.'
31.12: He said, 'Look up and see that all the male goats which are mating are striped, speckled, or spotted, because I have seen everything that Laban is doing to you.
31.13: I am the God who appeared to you at Bethel, where you poured olive oil on a stone marker for a holy purpose and where you made a vow to me. Now leave this land, and go back to the land of your relatives.' "
31.14: Rachel and Leah answered him, "Is there anything left in our father's household for us to inherit?
31.15: Doesn't he think of us as foreigners? Not only did he sell us, but he has used up the money that was paid for us.
31.16: Certainly, all the wealth that God took away from our father belongs to us and our children. Now do whatever God has told you."
31.17: Then Jacob put his children and his wives on camels.
31.18: He drove all his livestock ahead of him and took all the possessions that he had accumulated. He took his own livestock that he had accumulated in Paddan Aram and went back to his father Isaac in Canaan.
31.19: When Laban went to shear his sheep, Rachel stole her father's idols.
31.20: Jacob also tricked Laban the Aramean by not telling him he was leaving.
31.21: So he left in a hurry with all that belonged to him. He crossed the Euphrates River and went toward the mountains of Gilead.
31.22: Two days later Laban was told that Jacob had left in a hurry.
31.23: He and his relatives pursued Jacob for seven days. Laban caught up with him in the mountains of Gilead.
31.24: God came to Laban the Aramean in a dream at night and said to him, "Be careful not to say anything at all to Jacob."
31.25: When Laban finally caught up with Jacob, Jacob had put up his tents in the mountains. So Laban and his relatives put up their tents in the mountains of Gilead.
31.26: Then Laban asked Jacob, "What have you done by tricking me? You've carried off my daughters like prisoners of war.
31.27: Why did you leave secretly and trick me? You didn't even tell me you were leaving. I would have sent you on your way rejoicing, with songs accompanied by tambourines and lyres.
31.28: You didn't even let me kiss my grandchildren and my daughters. You've done a foolish thing.
31.29: I have the power to harm you. Last night the God of your father said to me, 'Be careful not to say anything at all to Jacob.'
31.30: Now you have left for your father's home because you were so homesick. But why did you steal my gods?"
31.31: Jacob answered Laban, "I left because I was afraid. I thought you would take your daughters away from me by force.
31.32: If you find your gods, the one who has them will not be allowed to live. In the presence of our relatives, search as much as you want through what I have, and take what is yours." (Jacob didn't know that Rachel had stolen the gods.)
31.33: So Laban went into Jacob's tent, into Leah's tent, and into the tent of the two slaves. But he found nothing. He came out of Leah's tent and went into Rachel's tent.
31.34: Rachel had taken the idols and had put them in her camel's saddle-bag and was sitting on them. Laban rummaged through the whole tent but found nothing.
31.35: Rachel said to her father, "Don't be angry, Father, but I can't get up to greet you; I'm having my period." So even though Laban had made a thorough search, he didn't find the idols.
31.36: Then Jacob became angry and confronted Laban. "What is my crime?" Jacob demanded of Laban. "What is my offense that you have come chasing after me?
31.37: Now that you've rummaged through all my things, did you find anything from your house? Put it here in front of all our relatives. Let them decide which one of us is right.
31.38: "I've been with you for 20 years. Your sheep and goats never miscarried, and I never ate any rams from your flocks.
31.39: I never brought you any of the flock that was killed by wild animals. I paid for the loss myself. That's what you demanded of me when any of the flock was stolen during the day or at night.
31.40: The scorching heat during the day and the cold at night wore me down, and I lost a lot of sleep.
31.41: I've been with your household 20 years now. I worked for you 14 years for your two daughters and 6 years for your flocks, and you changed my wages ten times.
31.42: If the God of my father, the God of Abraham and the Fear of Isaac, had not been with me, you would have sent me away empty-handed by now. God has seen my misery and hard work, and last night he made it right."
31.43: Then Laban answered Jacob, "These are my daughters, my grandchildren, and my flocks. Everything you see is mine! Yet, what can I do today for my daughters or for their children?
31.44: Now, let's make an agreement and let it stand as a witness between you and me."
31.45: Jacob took a stone and set it up as a marker.
31.46: Then Jacob said to his relatives, "Gather some stones." They took stones, put them into a pile, and ate there by the pile of stones.
31.47: [In his language] Laban called it Jegar Sahadutha [Witness Pile], but Jacob called it Galeed.
31.48: Laban said, "This pile of stones stands as a witness between you and me today." This is why it was named Galeed
31.49: and also Mizpah [Watchtower], because he said, "May the LORD watch between you and me when we're unable to see each other.
31.50: If you mistreat my daughters or marry other women behind my back, remember that God stands as a witness between you and me."
31.51: Laban said to Jacob, "Here is the pile of stones, and here is the marker that I have set up between you and me.
31.52: This pile of stones and this marker stand as witnesses that I will not go past the pile of stones to harm you, and that you will not go past the pile of stones or marker to harm me.
31.53: May the God of Abraham and Nahor-the God of their father-judge between us." So Jacob swore this oath by the Fear of his father Isaac
31.54: and offered a sacrifice on the mountain. He invited his relatives to eat the meal with him. They ate with him and spent the night on the mountain.
31.55: Early the next morning Laban kissed his grandchildren and his daughters and blessed them. Then Laban left and went back home.

32.1: As Jacob went on his way, God's angels met him.
32.2: When he saw them, Jacob said, "This is God's camp!" He named that place Mahanaim [Two Camps].
32.3: Jacob sent messengers ahead of him to his brother Esau in Seir, the country of Edom.
32.4: He commanded them to give this message to Esau, "Sir, this is what Jacob has to say, 'I've been living with Laban and have stayed until now.
32.5: I have cattle and donkeys, sheep and goats, and male and female slaves. I've sent [these messengers] to tell you [this news] in order to win your favor.'"
32.6: When the messengers came back to Jacob, they said, "We went to your brother Esau. He is coming to meet you with 400 men."
32.7: Jacob was terrified and distressed. So he divided the people, the sheep and goats, the cattle, and the camels into two camps.
32.8: He thought, "If Esau attacks the one camp, then the other camp will be able to escape."
32.9: Then Jacob prayed, "God of my grandfather Abraham and God of my father Isaac! LORD, you said to me, 'Go back to your land and to your relatives, and I will make you prosperous.'
32.10: I'm not worthy of all the love and faithfulness you have shown me. I only had a shepherd's staff when I crossed the Jordan River, but now I have two camps.
32.11: Please save me from my brother Esau, because I'm afraid of him. I'm afraid that he'll come and attack me and the mothers and children too.
32.12: But you did say, 'I will make sure that you are prosperous and that your descendants will be as many as the grains of sand on the seashore. No one will be able to count them because there are so many.'"
32.13: He stayed there that night. Then he prepared a gift for his brother Esau from what he had brought with him:
32.14: 200 female goats and 20 male goats, 200 female sheep and 20 male sheep,
32.15: 30 female camels with their young, 40 cows and 10 bulls, 20 female donkeys and 10 male donkeys.
32.16: He placed servants in charge of each herd. Then he said to his servants, "Go ahead of me, and keep a distance between the herds."
32.17: He commanded the first servant, "When my brother Esau meets you and asks you, 'To whom do you belong, and where are you going, and whose animals are these ahead of you?'
32.18: then say, 'Sir, they belong to your servant Jacob. This is a gift sent to you. Jacob is right behind us.'"
32.19: He also commanded the second servant, the third, and all the others who followed the herds. He said, "Say the same thing to Esau when you find him.
32.20: And be sure to add, 'Jacob is right behind us, sir.' " He thought, "I'll make peace with him by giving him this gift that I'm sending ahead of me. After that I will see him, and he'll welcome me back."
32.21: So Jacob sent the gift ahead of him while he stayed in the camp that night.
32.22: During that night he got up and gathered his two wives, his two slaves and his eleven children and crossed at the shallow part of the Jabbok River.
32.23: After he sent them across the stream, he sent everything else across.
32.24: So Jacob was left alone. Then a man wrestled with him until dawn.
32.25: When the man saw that he could not win against Jacob, he touched the socket of Jacob's hip so that it was dislocated as they wrestled.
32.26: Then the man said, "Let me go; it's almost dawn." But Jacob answered, "I won't let you go until you bless me."
32.27: So the man asked him, "What's your name?" "Jacob," he answered.
32.28: The man said, "Your name will no longer be Jacob but Israel [He Struggles With God], because you have struggled with God and with men-and you have won."
32.29: Jacob said, "Please tell me your name." The man answered, "Why do you ask for my name?" Then he blessed Jacob there.
32.30: So Jacob named that place Peniel [Face of God], because he said, "I have seen God face to face, but my life was saved."
32.31: The sun rose as he passed Penuel. He was limping because of his hip.
32.32: (Therefore, even today the people of Israel do not eat the muscle of the thigh attached to the hip socket because God touched the socket of Jacob's hip at the muscle of the thigh.)

33.1: Jacob saw Esau coming with 400 men. So he divided the children among Leah, Rachel, and the two slaves.
33.2: He put the slaves and their children in front, Leah and her children after them, and Rachel and Joseph last.
33.3: He went on ahead of them and bowed seven times with his face touching the ground as he came near his brother.
33.4: Then Esau ran to meet Jacob. Esau hugged him, threw his arms around him, and kissed him. They both cried.
33.5: When he saw the women and children, Esau asked, "Who are these people here with you?" "The children God has graciously given me, sir," Jacob answered.
33.6: Then the slaves and their children came forward and bowed down.
33.7: Likewise, Leah and her children came forward and bowed down. Finally, Joseph and Rachel came forward and bowed down.
33.8: Then Esau asked, "Why did you send this whole group [of people and animals] I met?" He answered, "To win your favor, sir."
33.9: Esau said, "I have enough. Keep what you have, Brother."
33.10: Jacob said, "No, please take the gift I'm giving you, because I've seen your face as if I were seeing the face of God, and yet you welcomed me so warmly.
33.11: Please take the present I've brought you, because God has been gracious to me and has given me all that I need." So Esau took it because Jacob insisted.
33.12: Then Esau said, "Let's get ready to go, and I'll go with you."
33.13: Jacob said to him, "Sir, you know that the children are frail and that I have to take care of the flocks and cattle that are nursing their young. If they're driven too hard for even one day, all the flocks will die.
33.14: Go ahead of me, sir. I will slowly and gently guide the herds that are in front of me at their pace and at the children's pace until I come to you in Seir."
33.15: Esau said, "Then let me leave some of my men with you." "Why do that?" Jacob asked. "I only want to win your favor, sir."
33.16: That day Esau started back to Seir.
33.17: But Jacob moved on to Succoth, where he built a house for himself and made shelters for his livestock. That is why the place is named Succoth [Shelters].
33.18: So having come from Paddan Aram, Jacob came safely to the city of Shechem in Canaan. He camped within sight of the city.
33.19: Then he bought the piece of land on which he had put up his tents. He bought it from the sons of Hamor, father of Shechem, for 100 pieces of silver.
33.20: He set up an altar there and named it God Is the God of Israel.

34.1: Dinah, daughter of Leah and Jacob, went out to visit some of the Canaanite women.
34.2: When Shechem, son of the local ruler Hamor the Hivite, saw her, he took her and raped her.
34.3: He became very fond of Jacob's daughter Dinah. He loved the girl and spoke tenderly to her.
34.4: So Shechem said to his father Hamor, "Get me this girl for my wife."
34.5: Jacob heard that Shechem had dishonored his daughter Dinah. His sons were with his livestock out in the open country, so Jacob kept quiet until they came home.
34.6: So Shechem's father Hamor came to Jacob to speak with him.
34.7: Jacob's sons came in from the open country as soon as they heard the news. The men felt outraged and very angry because Shechem had committed such a godless act against Israel's family by raping Jacob's daughter. This shouldn't have happened.
34.8: Hamor told them. "My son Shechem has his heart set on your daughter. Please let her marry him.
34.9: Intermarry with us; give your daughters to us, and take ours for yourselves.
34.10: You can live with us, and the land will be yours. Live here, move about freely in this area, and acquire property here."
34.11: Then Shechem said to Dinah's father and her brothers, "Do me this favor. I'll give you whatever you ask.
34.12: Set the price I must pay for the bride and the gift I must give her as high as you want. I'll pay exactly what you tell me. Give me the girl as my wife."
34.13: Then Jacob's sons gave Shechem and his father Hamor a misleading answer because he had dishonored their sister Dinah.
34.14: They said, "We can't do this. We can't give our sister to a man who is uncircumcised. That would be a disgrace to us!
34.15: We will give our consent to you only on one condition: Every male must be circumcised as we are.
34.16: Then we'll give our daughters to you and take yours for ourselves, and we'll live with you and become one people.
34.17: If you won't agree to be circumcised, we'll take our daughter and go."
34.18: Their proposal seemed good to Hamor and his son Shechem.
34.19: The young man didn't waste any time in doing what they said because he took such pleasure in Jacob's daughter. He was the most honored person in all his father's family.
34.20: So Hamor and his son Shechem went to their city gate to speak to the men of their city. They said,
34.21: "These people are friendly toward us, so let them live in our land and move about freely in the area. Look, there's plenty of room in this land for them. We can marry their daughters and let them marry ours.
34.22: These people will consent to live with us and become one nation on one condition: Every male must be circumcised as they are.
34.23: Won't their livestock, their personal property, and all their animals be ours? We only need to agree to do this for them. Then they'll live with us."
34.24: All the men who had come out to the city gate agreed with Hamor and his son Shechem. So they were all circumcised at the city gate.
34.25: Two days later, while the men were still in pain, two of Jacob's sons, Simeon and Levi, Dinah's brothers, took their swords and boldly attacked the city. They killed every man
34.26: including Hamor and his son Shechem. They took Dinah from Shechem's home and left.
34.27: Then Jacob's sons stripped the corpses and looted the city where their sister had been dishonored.
34.28: They took the sheep and goats, cattle, donkeys, and whatever else was in the city or out in the fields.
34.29: They carried off all the wealth and all the women and children and looted everything in the houses.
34.30: Then Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, "You have caused me a lot of trouble! You've made the people living in the area, the Canaanites and the Perizzites, hate me. There are only a few of us. If they join forces against me and attack me, my family and I will be wiped out."
34.31: Simeon and Levi asked, "Should Shechem have been allowed to treat our sister like a prostitute?"

35.1: Then God said to Jacob, "Go to Bethel and live there. Make an altar there. I am the God who appeared to you when you were fleeing from your brother Esau."
35.2: So Jacob said to his family and those who were with him, "Get rid of the foreign gods which you have, wash yourselves until you are ritually clean, and change your clothes.
35.3: Then let's go to Bethel. I will make an altar there to God, who answered me when I was troubled and who has been with me wherever I've gone."
35.4: So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods that they had in their possession as well as the earrings that they had on. Jacob buried these things under the oak tree near Shechem.
35.5: As they moved on, God made the people of the cities that were all around them terrified so that no one pursued them.
35.6: Jacob and all the people who were with him came to Luz (that is, Bethel) in the land of Canaan.
35.7: He built an altar there and called that place El Bethel [God of the House of God]. That's where God had revealed himself to Jacob when he was fleeing from his brother.
35.8: Rebekah's nurse Deborah died and was buried under the oak tree outside Bethel. So Jacob called it the Tree of Crying.
35.9: Then God appeared once more to Jacob after he came back from Paddan Aram, and he blessed him.
35.10: God said to him, "Your name is Jacob. You will no longer be called Jacob, but your name will be Israel." So he named him Israel.
35.11: God also said to him, "I am God Almighty. Be fertile, and increase in number. A nation and a community of nations will come from you, and kings will come from you.
35.12: I will give you the land that I gave to Abraham and Isaac. I will also give this land to your descendants."
35.13: Then God went up from him at the place where he had spoken with him.
35.14: So Jacob set up a memorial, a stone marker, to mark the place where God had spoken with him. He poured a wine offering and olive oil on it.
35.15: Jacob named the place where God had spoken with him Bethel [House of God].
35.16: Then they moved on from Bethel. When they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel went into labor and was having severe labor pains.
35.17: During one of her pains, the midwife said to her, "Don't be afraid! You're having another son!"
35.18: Rachel was dying. As she took her last breath, she named her son Benoni [Son of My Sorrow], but his father named him Benjamin [Son of My Right Hand].
35.19: Rachel died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).
35.20: Then Jacob set up a stone as a marker for her grave. The same marker is at Rachel's grave today.
35.21: Israel moved on again and put up his tent beyond Migdal Eder.
35.22: While Israel was living in that region, Reuben went to bed with his father's concubine Bilhah, and Israel heard about it. Jacob had 12 sons.
35.23: The sons of [Leah]were Jacob's firstborn Reuben, then Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, and Zebulun.
35.24: The sons of [Rachel]were Joseph and Benjamin.
35.25: The sons of Rachel's slave [Bilhah]were Dan and Naphtali.
35.26: The sons of Leah's slave [Zilpah]were Gad and Asher. These were Jacob's sons, who were born in Paddan Aram.
35.27: Jacob came home to his father Isaac to Mamre's city, Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron). Abraham and Isaac had lived there for a while.
35.29: when he took his last breath and died. He joined his ancestors in death at a very old age. His sons Esau and Jacob buried him.

36.1: This is the account of Esau (that is, Edom) and his descendants.
36.2: Esau chose his wives from the women of Canaan: Adah, daughter of Elon the Hittite; Oholibamah, daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon the Hivite;
36.3: also Basemath, daughter of Ishmael and sister of Nebaioth.
36.4: Adah gave birth to Eliphaz for Esau, and Basemath gave birth to Reuel.
36.5: Oholibamah gave birth to Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These were the sons of Esau who were born in Canaan.
36.6: Esau took his wives, his sons, his daughters, all the members of his household, his possessions, all his cattle, and everything he had accumulated in Canaan and went to another land away from his brother Jacob.
36.7: He did this because they had too many possessions to live together. There wasn't enough pastureland for all of their livestock.
36.8: So Esau, who was also known as Edom, lived in the mountains of Seir.
36.9: This is the account of Esau and his descendants. He was the father of the people of Edom in the mountains of Seir.
36.10: These were the names of Esau's sons: Eliphaz, son of Esau's wife Adah, and Reuel, son of Esau's wife Basemath.
36.11: The sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, and Kenaz.
36.12: Timna was a concubine of Esau's son Eliphaz. She gave birth to Amalek for Eliphaz. These were the grandsons of Esau's wife Adah.
36.13: These were Reuel's sons: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the grandsons of Esau's wife Basemath.
36.14: These were the sons of Esau's wife Oholibamah, daughter of Anah and granddaughter of Zibeon. She gave birth to Jeush, Jalam, and Korah for Esau.
36.15: These were the tribal leaders among Esau's descendants: The sons of Eliphaz, Esau's firstborn, were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Kenaz,
36.16: Korah, Gatam, and Amalek. These were the tribal leaders descended from Eliphaz in Edom. They were the grandsons of Adah.
36.17: These were the tribal leaders among the descendants of Esau's son Reuel: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah. These were the tribal leaders descended from Reuel in Edom. They were the grandsons of Esau's wife Basemath.
36.18: These were the tribal leaders among the descendants of Esau's wife Oholibamah: Jeush, Jalam, and Korah. These were the tribal leaders descended from Esau's wife Oholibamah, Anah's daughter.
36.19: These were the descendants of Esau (that is, Edom), who were tribal leaders.
36.20: These were the sons of Seir the Horite, the people living in that land: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
36.21: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These Horite tribal leaders were the sons of Seir in Edom.
36.22: The sons of Lotan were Hori and Hemam. Lotan's sister was Timna.
36.23: These were the sons of Shobal: Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
36.24: These were the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah. (Anah found the hot springs in the desert while he was taking care of the donkeys that belonged to his father Zibeon.)
36.25: These were the children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah, daughter of Anah.
36.26: These were the sons of Dishon: Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
36.27: These were the sons of Ezer: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
36.28: These were the sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
36.29: These were the Horite tribal leaders: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah,
36.30: Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. These were the Horite tribal leaders in the land of Seir.
36.31: These were the kings who ruled Edom before any king ruled the people of Israel:
36.32: Bela, son of Beor, ruled Edom. The name of his [capital] city was Dinhabah.
36.33: After Bela died, Jobab, son of Zerah from Bozrah, succeeded him as king.
36.34: After Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites succeeded him as king.
36.35: After Husham died, Hadad, son of Bedad succeeded him as king. Hadad defeated the Midianites in the country of Moab. The name of his capital city was Avith.
36.36: After Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah succeeded him as king.
36.37: After Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth on the river succeeded him as king.
36.38: After Shaul died, Baal Hanan, son of Achbor, succeeded him as king.
36.39: After Baal Hanan, son of Achbor, died, Hadar succeeded him as king, and the name of his capital city was Pau. His wife's name was Mehetabel, daughter of Matred and granddaughter of Mezahab.
36.40: These were the names of the tribal leaders descended from Esau, by family, place, and name: Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
36.43: Magdiel, and Iram. These were the tribal leaders of Edom listed by the places where they lived and the property they owned. Esau was the father of the people of Edom.

37.1: Jacob continued to live in the land of Canaan, where his father had lived.
37.2: This is the account of Jacob and his descendants. Joseph was a seventeen-year-old young man. He took care of the flocks with the sons of Bilhah and Zilpah, his father's wives. Joseph told his father about the bad things his brothers were doing.
37.3: Israel loved Joseph more than all his sons because Joseph had been born in Israel's old age. So he made Joseph a special robe with long sleeves.
37.4: Joseph's brothers saw that their father loved him more than any of them. They hated Joseph and couldn't speak to him on friendly terms.
37.5: Joseph had a dream and when he told his brothers, they hated him even more.
37.6: He said to them, "Please listen to the dream I had.
37.7: We were tying grain into bundles out in the field, and suddenly mine stood up. It remained standing while your bundles gathered around my bundle and bowed down to it."
37.8: Then his brothers asked him, "Are you going to be our king or rule us?" They hated him even more for his dreams and his words.
37.9: Then he had another dream, and he told it to his brothers. "Listen," he said, "I had another dream: I saw the sun, the moon, and 11 stars bowing down to me."
37.10: When he told his father and his brothers, his father criticized him by asking, "What's this dream you had? Will your mother and I and your brothers come and bow down in front of you?"
37.11: So his brothers were jealous of him, but his father kept thinking about these things.
37.12: His brothers had gone to take care of their father's flocks at Shechem.
37.13: Israel then said to Joseph, "Your brothers are taking care of the flocks at Shechem. I'm going to send you to them." Joseph responded, "I'll go."
37.14: So Israel said, "See how your brothers and the flocks are doing, and bring some news back to me." Then he sent Joseph away from the Hebron Valley. When Joseph came to Shechem,
37.15: a man found him wandering around in the open country. "What are you looking for?" the man asked.
37.16: Joseph replied, "I'm looking for my brothers. Please tell me where they're taking care of their flocks."
37.17: The man said, "They moved on from here. I heard them say, 'Let's go to Dothan.' " So Joseph went after his brothers and found them at Dothan.
37.18: They saw him from a distance. Before he reached them, they plotted to kill him.
37.19: They said to each other, "Look, here comes that master dreamer!
37.20: Let's kill him, throw him into one of the cisterns, and say that a wild animal has eaten him. Then we'll see what happens to his dreams."
37.21: When Reuben heard this, he tried to save Joseph from their plot. "Let's not kill him," he said.
37.22: "Let's not have any bloodshed. Put him into that cistern that's out in the desert, but don't hurt him." Reuben wanted to rescue Joseph from them and bring him back to his father.
37.23: So when Joseph reached his brothers, they stripped him of his special robe with long sleeves.
37.24: Then they took him and put him into an empty cistern. It had no water in it.
37.25: As they sat down to eat, they saw a caravan of Ishmaelites coming from Gilead. Their camels were carrying the materials for cosmetics, medicine, and embalming. They were on their way to take them to Egypt.
37.26: Judah asked his brothers, "What will we gain by killing our brother and covering up his death?
37.27: Let's sell him to the Ishmaelites. Let's not hurt him, because he is our brother, our own flesh and blood." His brothers agreed.
37.28: As the Midianite merchants were passing by, the brothers pulled Joseph out of the cistern. They sold him to the Ishmaelites for eight ounces of silver. The Ishmaelites took him to Egypt.
37.29: When Reuben came back to the cistern and saw that Joseph was no longer there, he tore his clothes in grief.
37.30: He went back to his brothers and said, "The boy isn't there! What am I going to do?"
37.31: So they took Joseph's robe, killed a goat, and dipped the robe in the blood.
37.32: Then they brought the special robe with long sleeves to their father and said, "We found this. You better examine it to see whether it's your son's robe or not."
37.33: He recognized it and said, "It is my son's robe! A wild animal has eaten him! Joseph must have been torn to pieces!"
37.34: Then, to show his grief, Jacob tore his clothes, put sackcloth around his waist, and mourned for his son a long time.
37.35: All his other sons and daughters came to comfort him, but he refused to be comforted. He said, "No, I will mourn for my son until I die." This is how Joseph's father cried over him.
37.36: Meanwhile, in Egypt the Midianites sold Joseph to Potiphar, one of Pharaoh's officials and captain of the guard.

38.1: About that time Judah left his brothers and went to stay with a man from Adullam whose name was Hirah.
38.2: There Judah met the daughter of a Canaanite man whose name was Shua. He married her and slept with her.
38.3: She became pregnant and gave birth to a son named Er.
38.4: She became pregnant again and gave birth to another son, whom she named Onan.
38.5: Then she became pregnant again and gave birth to another son, whom she named Shelah. He was born at Kezib.
38.6: Judah chose a wife for his firstborn son Er. Her name was Tamar.
38.7: Er angered the LORD. So the LORD took away his life.
38.8: Then Judah said to Onan, "Go sleep with your brother's widow. Do your duty for her as a brother-in-law, and produce a descendant for your brother."
38.9: But Onan knew that the descendant wouldn't belong to him, so whenever he slept with his brother's widow, he wasted his semen on the ground to avoid giving his brother a descendant.
38.10: What Onan did angered the LORD so much that the LORD took away Onan's life too.
38.11: Then Judah said to his daughter-in-law Tamar, "Return to your father's home. Live as a widow until my son Shelah grows up." He thought that this son, too, might die like his brothers. So Tamar went to live in her father's home.
38.12: After a long time Judah's wife, the daughter of Shua, died. When Judah had finished mourning, he and his friend Hirah from Adullam went to Timnah where the men were shearing Judah's sheep.
38.13: As soon as Tamar was told that her father-in-law was on his way to Timnah to shear his sheep,
38.14: she took off her widow's clothes, covered her face with a veil, and disguised herself. Then she sat down at the entrance to Enaim, which is on the road to Timnah. (She did this because she realized that Shelah was grown up now, and she hadn't been given to him in marriage.)
38.15: When Judah saw her, he thought she was a prostitute because she had covered her face.
38.16: Since he didn't know she was his daughter-in-law, he approached her by the roadside and said, "Come on, let's sleep together!" She asked, "What will you pay to sleep with me?"
38.17: "I'll send you a young goat from the flock," he answered. She said, "First give me something as a deposit until you send it."
38.18: "What should I give you as a deposit?" he asked. "Your signet ring, its cord, and the shepherd's staff that's in your hand," she answered. So he gave them to her. Then he slept with her, and she became pregnant.
38.19: After she got up and left, she took off her veil and put her widow's clothes back on.
38.20: Judah sent his friend Hirah to deliver the young goat so that he could get back his deposit from the woman, but his friend couldn't find her.
38.21: He asked the men of that area, "Where's that prostitute who was beside the road at Enaim?" "There's no prostitute here," they answered.
38.22: So he went back to Judah and said, "I couldn't find her. Even the men of that area said, 'There's no prostitute here.'"
38.23: Then Judah said, "Let her keep what I gave her, or we'll become a laughingstock. After all, I did send her this young goat, but you couldn't find her."
38.24: About three months later Judah was told, "Your daughter-in-law Tamar has been acting like a prostitute. What's more, because of it she's pregnant." Judah ordered, "Bring her out to be burned."
38.25: As she was brought out, she sent a message to her father-in-law, "I'm pregnant by the man who owns these things. See if you recognize whose signet ring, cord, and shepherd's staff these are."
38.26: Judah recognized them and said, "She's not guilty. I am! She did this because I haven't given her my son Shelah." Judah never made love to her again.
38.27: The time came for Tamar to give birth, and she had twin boys.
38.28: When she was giving birth, one of them put out his hand. The midwife took a piece of red yarn, tied it on his wrist, and said, "This one came out first."
38.29: As he pulled back his hand, his brother was born. So she said, "Is this how you burst into the world!" He was named Perez [Bursting Into].
38.30: After that his brother was born with the red yarn on his hand. He was named Zerah [Sunrise].

39.1: Joseph had been taken to Egypt. Potiphar, one of Pharaoh's Egyptian officials and captain of the guard, bought him from the Ishmaelites who had taken him there.
39.2: The LORD was with Joseph, so he became a successful man. He worked in the house of his Egyptian master.
39.3: Joseph's master saw that the LORD was with him and that the LORD made everything he did successful.
39.4: Potiphar liked Joseph so much that he made him his trusted servant. He put him in charge of his household and everything he owned.
39.5: From that time on the LORD blessed the Egyptian's household because of Joseph. Therefore, the LORD's blessing was on everything Potiphar owned in his house and in his fields.
39.6: So he left all that he owned in Joseph's care. He wasn't concerned about anything except the food he ate. Joseph was well-built and handsome.
39.7: After a while his master's wife began to desire Joseph, so she said, "Come to bed with me."
39.8: But Joseph refused and said to her, "My master doesn't concern himself with anything in the house. He trusts me with everything he owns.
39.9: No one in this house is greater than I. He's kept nothing back from me except you, because you're his wife. How could I do such a wicked thing and sin against God?"
39.10: Although she kept asking Joseph day after day, he refused to go to bed with her or be with her.
39.11: One day he went into the house to do his work, and none of the household servants were there.
39.12: She grabbed him by his clothes and said, "Come to bed with me!" But he ran outside and left his clothes in her hand.
39.13: When she realized that he had gone but had left his clothes behind,
39.14: she called her household servants and said to them, "Look! My husband brought this Hebrew here to fool around with us. He came in and tried to go to bed with me, but I screamed as loud as I could.
39.15: As soon as he heard me scream, he ran outside and left his clothes with me."
39.16: She kept Joseph's clothes with her until his master came home.
39.17: Then she told him the same story: "The Hebrew slave you brought here came in and tried to fool around with me.
39.18: But when I screamed, he ran outside and left his clothes with me."
39.19: When Potiphar heard his wife's story, especially when she said, "This is what your slave did to me," he became very angry.
39.20: So Joseph's master arrested him and put him in the same prison where the king's prisoners were kept. While Joseph was in prison,
39.21: the LORD was with him. The LORD reached out to him with his unchanging love and gave him protection. The LORD also put Joseph on good terms with the warden.
39.22: So the warden placed Joseph in charge of all the prisoners who were in that prison. Joseph became responsible for everything that they were doing.
39.23: The warden paid no attention to anything under Joseph's care because the LORD was with Joseph and made whatever he did successful.

40.1: Later the king's cupbearer and his baker offended their master, the king of Egypt.
40.2: Pharaoh was angry with his chief cupbearer and his chief baker.
40.3: He put them in the prison of the captain of the guard, the same place where Joseph was a prisoner.
40.4: The captain of the guard assigned them to Joseph, and he took care of them. After they had been confined for some time,
40.5: both prisoners-the cupbearer and the baker for the king of Egypt-had dreams one night. Each man had a dream with its own special meaning.
40.6: When Joseph came to them in the morning, he saw that they were upset.
40.7: So he asked these officials of Pharaoh who were with him in his master's prison, "Why do you look so unhappy today?"
40.8: "We both had dreams," they answered him, "but there's no one to tell us what they mean." "Isn't God the only one who can tell what they mean?" Joseph asked them. "Why don't you tell me all about them."
40.9: So the chief cupbearer told Joseph his dream. He said "In my dream a grapevine with three branches appeared in front of me.
40.10: Soon after it sprouted it blossomed. Then its clusters ripened into grapes.
40.11: Pharaoh's cup was in my hand, so I took the grapes and squeezed them into it. I put the cup in Pharaoh's hand."
40.12: "This is what it means," Joseph said to him. "The three branches are three days.
40.13: In the next three days Pharaoh will release you and restore you to your position. You will put Pharaoh's cup in his hand as you used to do when you were his cupbearer.
40.14: Remember me when things go well for you, and please do me a favor. Mention me to Pharaoh, and get me out of this prison.
40.15: I was kidnapped from the land of the Hebrews, and even here I've done nothing to deserve being put in this prison."
40.16: The chief baker saw that the meaning Joseph had given to the cupbearer's dream was good. So he said to Joseph, "I had a dream too. In my dream three baskets of white baked goods were on my head.
40.17: The top basket contained all kinds of baked goods for Pharaoh, but the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head."
40.18: "This is what it means," Joseph replied. "The three baskets are three days.
40.19: In the next three days Pharaoh will cut off your head and hang your dead body on a pole. The birds will eat the flesh from your bones."
40.20: Two days later, on his birthday, Pharaoh had a special dinner prepared for all his servants. Of all his servants he gave special attention to the chief cupbearer and the chief baker.
40.21: He restored the chief cupbearer to his position. So the cupbearer put the cup in Pharaoh's hand.
40.22: But he hung the chief baker just as Joseph had said in his interpretation.
40.23: Nevertheless, the chief cupbearer didn't remember Joseph. He forgot all about him.

41.1: After two full years Pharaoh had a dream. He dreamed he was standing by the Nile River.
41.2: Suddenly, seven nice-looking, well-fed cows came up from the river and began to graze among the reeds.
41.3: Seven other cows came up from the river behind them. These cows were sickly and skinny. They stood behind the first seven cows on the riverbank.
41.4: The cows that were sickly and skinny ate the seven nice-looking, well-fed cows. Then Pharaoh woke up.
41.5: He fell asleep again and had a second dream. Seven good, healthy heads of grain were growing on a single stalk.
41.6: Seven other heads of grain, thin and scorched by the east wind, sprouted behind them.
41.7: The thin heads of grain swallowed the seven full, healthy heads. Then Pharaoh woke up. It was only a dream.
41.8: In the morning he was so upset that he sent for all the magicians and wise men of Egypt. Pharaoh told them his dreams, but no one could tell him what they meant.
41.9: Then the chief cupbearer spoke to Pharaoh, "I remember a promise I failed to keep.
41.10: Some time ago when Pharaoh was angry with his servants, he confined me and the chief baker to the captain of the guard's prison.
41.11: We both had dreams the same night. Each dream had its own meaning.
41.12: A young Hebrew, a slave of the captain of the guard, was with us. We told him our dreams, and he told each of us what they meant.
41.13: What he told us happened: Pharaoh restored me to my position, but he hung the baker on a pole."
41.14: Then Pharaoh sent for Joseph, and immediately he was brought from the prison. After he had shaved and changed his clothes, he came in front of Pharaoh.
41.15: Pharaoh said to Joseph, "I had a dream, and no one can tell me what it means. I heard that when you are told a dream, you can say what it means."
41.16: Joseph answered Pharaoh, "I can't, but God can give Pharaoh the answer that he needs."
41.17: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, "In my dream I was standing on the bank of the Nile.
41.18: Suddenly, seven nice-looking, well-fed cows came up from the river and began to graze among the reeds.
41.19: Seven other cows came up behind them. These cows were scrawny, very sick, and thin. I've never seen such sickly cows in all of Egypt!
41.20: The thin, sickly cows ate up the seven well-fed ones.
41.21: Even though they had eaten them, no one could tell they had eaten them. They looked just as sick as before. Then I woke up.
41.22: "In my second dream I saw seven good, full heads of grain growing on a single stalk.
41.23: Seven other heads of grain, withered, thin, and scorched by the east wind, sprouted behind them.
41.24: The thin heads of grain swallowed the seven good heads. I told this to the magicians, but no one could tell me what it meant."
41.25: Then Joseph said to Pharaoh, "Pharaoh had the same dream twice. God has told Pharaoh what he's going to do.
41.26: The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good heads of grain are seven years. It's all the same dream.
41.27: The seven thin, sickly cows that came up behind them are seven years. The seven empty heads of grain scorched by the east wind are also seven years. Seven years of famine are coming.
41.28: "It's just as I said to Pharaoh. God has shown Pharaoh what he's going to do.
41.29: Seven years are coming when there will be plenty of food in Egypt.
41.30: After them will come seven years of famine. People will forget that there was plenty of food in Egypt, and the famine will ruin the land.
41.31: People won't remember that there once was plenty of food in the land, because the coming famine will be so severe.
41.32: The reason Pharaoh has had a recurring dream is because the matter has been definitely decided by God, and he will do it very soon.
41.33: "Pharaoh should look for a wise and intelligent man and put him in charge of Egypt.
41.34: Make arrangements to appoint supervisors over the land to take a fifth of Egypt's harvest during the seven good years.
41.35: Have them collect all the food during these good years and store up grain under Pharaoh's control, to be kept for food in the cities.
41.36: This food will be a reserve supply for our country during the seven years of famine that will happen in Egypt. Then the land will not be ruined by the famine."
41.37: Pharaoh and all his servants liked the idea.
41.38: So Pharaoh asked his servants, "Can we find anyone like this-a man who has God's Spirit in him?"
41.39: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, "Because God has let you know all this, there is no one as wise and intelligent as you.
41.40: You will be in charge of my palace, and all my people will do what you say. I will be more important than you, only because I'm Pharaoh."
41.41: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, "I now put you in charge of Egypt."
41.42: Then Pharaoh took off his signet ring and put it on Joseph's finger. He had Joseph dressed in robes of fine linen and put a gold chain around his neck.
41.43: He had him ride in the chariot of the second-in-command. Men ran ahead of him and shouted, "Make way!" Pharaoh put Joseph in charge of Egypt.
41.44: He also said to Joseph, "Even though I am Pharaoh, no one anywhere in Egypt will do anything without your permission."
41.45: Pharaoh named Joseph Zaphenathpaneah and gave him Asenath as his wife. She was the daughter of Potiphera, priest from the city of On. Joseph traveled around Egypt.
41.46: Joseph was 30 years old when he entered the service of Pharaoh (the king of Egypt). He left Pharaoh and traveled all around Egypt.
41.47: During the seven good years the land produced large harvests.
41.48: Joseph collected all the food grown in Egypt during those seven years and put this food in the cities. In each city he put the food from the fields around it.
41.49: Joseph stored up grain in huge quantities like the sand on the seashore. He had so much that he finally gave up keeping any records because he couldn't measure it all.
41.50: Before the years of famine came, Joseph had two sons by Asenath, daughter of Potiphera, priest from the city of On.
41.51: Joseph named his firstborn son Manasseh [He Helps Me Forget], because God helped him forget all his troubles and all about his father's family.
41.52: He named the second son Ephraim [Blessed Twice With Children], because God gave him children in the land where he had suffered.
41.53: The seven years when there was plenty of food in Egypt came to an end.
41.54: Then the seven years of famine began as Joseph had said they would. All the other countries were experiencing famine. Yet, there was food in Egypt.
41.55: When everyone in Egypt began to feel the effects of the famine, the people cried to Pharaoh for food. But Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, "Go to Joseph! Do what he tells you!"
41.56: When the famine had spread all over the country, Joseph opened all the storehouses and sold grain to the Egyptians. He did this because the famine was severe in Egypt.
41.57: The whole world came to Joseph in Egypt to buy grain, since the famine was so severe all over the world.

42.1: When Jacob found out that grain was for sale in Egypt, he said to his sons, "Why do you keep looking at each other?
42.2: I've heard there's grain for sale in Egypt. Go there and buy some for us so that we won't starve to death."
42.3: Ten of Joseph's brothers went to buy grain in Egypt.
42.4: Jacob wouldn't send Joseph's brother Benjamin with the other brothers, because he was afraid that something would happen to him.
42.5: Israel's sons left with the others who were going to buy grain, because there was also famine in Canaan.
42.6: As governor of the country, Joseph was selling grain to everyone. So when Joseph's brothers arrived, they bowed in front of him with their faces touching the ground.
42.7: As soon as Joseph saw his brothers, he recognized them. But he acted as if he didn't know them and spoke harshly to them. "Where did you come from?" he asked them. "From Canaan, to buy food," they answered.
42.8: Even though Joseph recognized his brothers, they didn't recognize him.
42.9: Then he remembered the dreams he once had about them. "You're spies!" he said to them, "And you've come to find out where our country is unprotected."
42.10: "No, sir!" they answered him. "We've come to buy food.
42.11: We're all sons of one man. We're honest men, not spies."
42.12: He said to them, "No! You've come to find out where our country is unprotected."
42.13: They answered him, "We were 12 brothers, sons of one man in Canaan. The youngest brother stayed with our father, and the other one is no longer with us."
42.14: "It's just as I told you," Joseph said to them. "You're spies!
42.15: This is how you'll be tested: I solemnly swear, as surely as Pharaoh lives, that you won't leave this place unless your youngest brother comes here.
42.16: One of you must be sent to get your brother while the rest of you stay in prison. We'll see if you're telling the truth. If not, I solemnly swear, as surely as Pharaoh lives, you are spies!"
42.17: Then he put them in jail for three days.
42.18: On the third day Joseph said to them, "Do this, and you will live. I, too, fear God.
42.19: If you are honest men, you will let one of your brothers stay here in prison. The rest of you will go and take grain back to your starving families.
42.20: But you must bring me your youngest brother. This will show that you've been telling the truth. Then you won't die." So they agreed.
42.21: They said to each other, "We're surely being punished for what we did to our brother. We saw how troubled he was when he pleaded with us for mercy, but we wouldn't listen. That's why we're in trouble now."
42.22: Reuben said to them, "Didn't I tell you not to sin against the boy? But you wouldn't listen. Now we must pay for this bloodshed."
42.23: They didn't know that Joseph could understand them, because he was speaking through an interpreter.
42.24: He stepped away from them to cry. When he could speak to them again, he came back. Then he picked Simeon and had him arrested right in front of their eyes.
42.25: Joseph gave orders to fill their bags with grain. He put each man's money back into his sack and gave them supplies for their trip. After their bags were filled,
42.26: they loaded their grain on their donkeys and left.
42.27: At the place where they stopped for the night, one of them opened his sack to feed his donkey. His money was right inside his sack.
42.28: He said to his brothers, "My money has been put back! It's right here in my sack!" They wanted to die. They trembled and turned to each other and asked, "What has God done to us?"
42.29: When they came to their father Jacob in Canaan, they told him all that had happened to them. They said,
42.30: "The governor of that land spoke harshly to us and treated us like spies.
42.31: But we said to him, 'We're honest men, not spies.
42.32: We were 12 brothers, sons of the same father. One is no longer with us. The youngest brother stayed with our father in Canaan.'
42.33: "Then the governor of that land said to us, 'This is how I'll know that you're honest men: Leave one of your brothers with me. Take food for your starving families and go.
42.34: But bring me your youngest brother. Then I'll know that you're not spies but honest men. I'll give your brother back to you, and you'll be able to move about freely in this country.'"
42.35: As they were emptying their sacks, each man found his bag of money in his sack. When they and their father saw the bags of money, they were frightened.
42.36: Their father Jacob said to them, "You're going to make me lose all my children! Joseph is no longer with us, Simeon is no longer with us, and now you want to take Benjamin. Everything's against me!"
42.37: So Reuben said to his father, "You may put my two sons to death if I don't bring him back to you. Let me take care of him, and I'll bring him back to you."
42.38: Jacob replied, "My son will not go with you. His brother is dead, and he's the only one left. If any harm comes to him on the trip you're taking, the grief would drive this gray-haired old man to his grave!"

43.1: The famine was severe in the land.
43.2: When they finished eating the grain they had brought from Egypt, Israel said to his sons, "Go back and buy us a little more food."
43.3: Judah said to him, "The man gave us a severe warning: 'You won't be allowed to see me again unless your brother is with you.'
43.4: If you let our brother go with us, we'll go and buy food for you.
43.5: If you won't let him go, we won't go. The man said to us, 'You won't be allowed to see me again unless your brother is with you.'"
43.6: Israel asked, "Why have you made trouble for me by telling the man you had another brother?"
43.7: They answered, "The man kept asking about us and our family: 'Is your father still alive? Do you have another brother?' We simply answered his questions. How could we possibly know he would say, 'Bring your brother here'?"
43.8: Then Judah said to his father Israel, "Send the boy along with me. Let's get going so that we won't starve to death.
43.9: I guarantee that he will come back. You can hold me responsible for him. If I don't bring him back to you and place him here in front of you, you can blame me the rest of my life.
43.10: If we hadn't waited so long, we could have made this trip twice by now."
43.11: Then their father Israel said to them, "If that's the way it has to be, then take the man a gift. Put some of the best products of the land in your bags. Take a little balm, a little honey, gum, myrrh, pistachio nuts, and almonds.
43.12: Take twice as much money with you. You must return the money that was put back in your sacks. Maybe it was a mistake.
43.13: Take your brother, and go back to the man.
43.14: May God Almighty make him merciful to you so that he will send your other brother and Benjamin [home] with you. If I lose my children, I lose my children."
